qas.question: What inhibited North Carolina for thousands of years?
Before 200 AD, people built what kind of mounds for religious purposes?
Who continued to build on to the religious mounds?
Before European contact, who built large cities and regional trading networks?
What was the largest city in the Piedmont before European contact?

context: North Carolina was inhabited for thousands of years by succeeding cultures of <a0_0>prehistoric indigenous cultures<a0_0/>. Before 200 AD, they were building <a1_0>earthwork<a1_0/> mounds, which were used for ceremonial and religious purposes. <a2_0>Succeeding peoples<a2_0/>, including those of the ancient Mississippian culture established by 1000 AD in the Piedmont, continued to build or add on to such mounds. In the 500–700 years preceding European contact, the <a3_0>Mississippian culture<a3_0/> built large, complex cities and maintained far-flung regional trading networks. Its largest city was <a4_0>Cahokia<a4_0/>, located in present-day Illinois near the Mississippi River.
